hawaiian_text: Noho ihola i laila, mahi ‘ai, ‘elua āna mau māla  ‘uala lō‘ihi e waiho nei ā hiki i kēia lā, a ua kapa ‘ia  ka inoa o ia mau māla, ‘o Nāmakaokapāo‘o ā hiki i  kēia lā. A o‘o ka ‘uala, ‘ōlelo ‘o Puali‘i i kāna ‘ōlelo   ho‘ohiki, “Aia ā kālua ke po‘o o ka ulua me ka ‘uala,  a ‘ai ‘o Puali‘i, a laila, noa, ‘ai kāna wahine, Pōka‘ī a  me nā mea ‘ē a‘e. No laila, iho akula ‘o Puali‘i i kai  o Honouliuli e lawai‘a i i‘a ‘ai pū me ka ‘uala.
llama-3.3-70B-Instruct_exl2_6.0bpw-maui_: Nāmakaokapāo'o stayed there, farming, and had two large sweet potato fields that still exist today, and those fields were named after him and still bear his name to this day. When the sweet potatoes were mature, Puali'i spoke his wish, "When the head of the ulua fish is cooked with sweet potatoes, then Puali'i will eat, and afterwards, his wife, Pōka'ī, and the others will eat." Therefore, Puali'i went down to the sea of Honouliuli to fish for fish to eat with sweet potatoes.

**Paragraph 4:** 
• The narrative continues with Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo'o settling down and engaging in farming activities, specifically cultivating sweet potatoes ('uala) in two large fields (māla 'uala lōʻihi) that are said to still exist today. 
– The fact that these fields are named after him (ka inoa o ia mau māla, ‘o Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o) suggests a strong connection between Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo'o and the land, as well as his significant impact on the community.
• Puali'i's statement regarding the cooking of ulua fish with sweet potatoes is noteworthy: 
– The use of ulua (a type of fish) in this context may allude to its cultural significance, particularly in the 'Ai Kapu era, where ulua was used as a substitute for human sacrifice due to its name's homophony with the word for "to grow" or "to increase."
– The phrase "Aia ā kālua ke po‘o o ka ulua me ka ‘uala" implies a ritual or ceremonial act, possibly symbolizing the transition from a period of scarcity to one of abundance, with the ulua and sweet potatoes representing the connection between the sea and the land, or the divine and the mundane.
• The structure of Puali'i's statement, "then Puali'i will eat, and afterwards, his wife, Pōka'ī, and the others will eat," reflects the hierarchical nature of 'Ai Kapu society, where the ali'i (chief) eats first, followed by others of lower rank.
– This hierarchical structure is also evident in the allocation of food resources, with Puali'i, as the chief, having priority access to the food, and Pōka'ī, his wife, eating afterwards, highlighting the societal norms of the time.
• Puali'i's decision to go fishing in the sea of Honouliuli to accompany the sweet potatoes with fish may symbolize the balance between the mahina 'ai (farming and cultivation) and the mahina kalai (fishing and seafood gathering), reflecting the dual economy of ancient Hawaiian society.
– The choice of location, Honouliuli, may hold cultural or historical significance, potentially relating to the story's themes of abundance, fertility, or the connection between the land and the sea.
• The name Pō-ka-‘ī (Puali'i's wife) may be interpreted as "night falls upon the high chief," suggesting a connection to the spiritual or mystical realm, and potentially signifying her role as a mediator between the divine and the mundane.
– The etymology of Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo'o's name, with Nā-maka- referring to "the eyes" and o-ka-pāo'o potentially alluding to the pāo'o fish, may be seen as symbolic of his role as a bridge between different realms or dimensions, with the eyes representing insight, wisdom, or the ability to see beyond the ordinary.
raw_response:
<translation>Nāmakaokapāo'o stayed there, farming, and had two large sweet potato fields that still exist today, and those fields were named after him and still bear his name to this day. When the sweet potatoes were mature, Puali'i spoke his wish, "When the head of the ulua fish is cooked with sweet potatoes, then Puali'i will eat, and afterwards, his wife, Pōka'ī, and the others will eat." Therefore, Puali'i went down to the sea of Honouliuli to fish for fish to eat with sweet potatoes.</translation>

<commentary>**Paragraph 4:** 
• The narrative continues with Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo'o settling down and engaging in farming activities, specifically cultivating sweet potatoes ('uala) in two large fields (māla 'uala lōʻihi) that are said to still exist today. 
– The fact that these fields are named after him (ka inoa o ia mau māla, ‘o Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o) suggests a strong connection between Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo'o and the land, as well as his significant impact on the community.
• Puali'i's statement regarding the cooking of ulua fish with sweet potatoes is noteworthy: 
– The use of ulua (a type of fish) in this context may allude to its cultural significance, particularly in the 'Ai Kapu era, where ulua was used as a substitute for human sacrifice due to its name's homophony with the word for "to grow" or "to increase."
– The phrase "Aia ā kālua ke po‘o o ka ulua me ka ‘uala" implies a ritual or ceremonial act, possibly symbolizing the transition from a period of scarcity to one of abundance, with the ulua and sweet potatoes representing the connection between the sea and the land, or the divine and the mundane.
• The structure of Puali'i's statement, "then Puali'i will eat, and afterwards, his wife, Pōka'ī, and the others will eat," reflects the hierarchical nature of 'Ai Kapu society, where the ali'i (chief) eats first, followed by others of lower rank.
– This hierarchical structure is also evident in the allocation of food resources, with Puali'i, as the chief, having priority access to the food, and Pōka'ī, his wife, eating afterwards, highlighting the societal norms of the time.
• Puali'i's decision to go fishing in the sea of Honouliuli to accompany the sweet potatoes with fish may symbolize the balance between the mahina 'ai (farming and cultivation) and the mahina kalai (fishing and seafood gathering), reflecting the dual economy of ancient Hawaiian society.
– The choice of location, Honouliuli, may hold cultural or historical significance, potentially relating to the story's themes of abundance, fertility, or the connection between the land and the sea.
• The name Pō-ka-‘ī (Puali'i's wife) may be interpreted as "night falls upon the high chief," suggesting a connection to the spiritual or mystical realm, and potentially signifying her role as a mediator between the divine and the mundane.
– The etymology of Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo'o's name, with Nā-maka- referring to "the eyes" and o-ka-pāo'o potentially alluding to the pāo'o fish, may be seen as symbolic of his role as a bridge between different realms or dimensions, with the eyes representing insight, wisdom, or the ability to see beyond the ordinary.</commentary>
reference_translation: They lived there and farmed, and Puali‘i had two  long sweet potato patches that remain until today,  and the patches were given the name,   Nāmakaokapāo‘o until today. When the sweet  potatoes were mature, Puali‘i said made a  promise, saying, “I’ll cook the head of an ulua fish  in the imu along with some sweet potatoes. When  Puali‘i eats, then the food will be made free for his  woman, Pōka‘ī, and anyone else.” So, Puali‘i went  down to the shore of Honouliuli to fish for a catch  to eat with sweet potatoes.
reference_commentary: **Paragraph 4:**• Pua-li‘i is a farmer with 2 long sweet potato patches  that lasted until the publication of this story. The  name of this sweet potato garden was known as *Nā maka-o-ka-pāo‘o*, the name of Pō-ka-‘ī’s son, and  victorious hero of the story;  • When the sweet potatoes were ready for harvest,  Pua-li‘i said that when he eats ulua fish with sweet  potatoes, cooked in the imu. The food would then be  made free for others, particularly Pō-ka-‘ī and Nā maka-o-ka-pāo‘o after he eats.  – The emphasis on Pua-li‘i, a male and head of the  family, eating, with his woman and child being  allowed to eat separately after he was done, is a  custom of ‘Ai Kapu culture;  • Having announced the eating routine/schedule, Pua li‘i then went to Hono-uliuli (dark bay) to fish for  ulua.  – The choice of ulua to eat with the ‘uala (sweet  potato) is likely due to the similarity in the   pronunciation of the two words, signifying ʻwhat is  above, so below,’ an old and recurring esoteric  feature of Hawaiian prosidy and culture, with a  lesson that there should always be balance in life  and in human practices (above-below; left-right;  male-female). This is the essence of ʻpono’;
